properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow with local blowing snow today. Snow at times heavy is expected today. Snowfall amounts in the 10 to 15 cm range are forecast for eastern portions of the region by this morning then for northeastern portions later today. A snowfall warning may be required. In addition, visibilities will be reduced in snow and blowing snow as northwesterly winds gust up to 50 km/h. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-05T21:35:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T05:36:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1345224649.2019
Area: Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: A Flood Warning Is Being Issued For The Roseau River At Gardenton
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Warning for the Roseau River at Gardenton due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe.
Expires: 2019-11-05T15:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-04T14:13:15-06:00, 85355D22-22B9-5AFF-E237-C2E82A2DFAEE
Area: The Roseau River at Gardenton
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River At Dominion City And Stuartburn
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River at Dominion City and Stuartburn due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-05T15:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-04T14:15:49-06:00, EBE6F468-6DE4-B384-AECB-D5E2F8B102F1
Area: Roseau River at Dominion City and Stuartburn
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight and Wednesday. Cold westerly flow over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior is expected to produce isolated snow squalls beginning tonight. The snow squall bands are expected to temporarily move over the region tonight and possibly on Wednesday. Locally heavy snowfall accumulations are possible along with reduced visibilities at times. Driving is expected to be hazardous at times tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T08:17:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T16:18:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1346710495.2019
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

Snowfall amounts in the 10 to 15 cm range are likely before the snow tapers off Wednesday morning. A snowfall warning may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Snow will continue into Wednesday and will be heavy at times. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are likely in some place before the heaviest snow tapers off Wednesday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T08:29:02-00:00

Area: Peawanuck

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Cold westerly flow over the relatively warm waters of Lake Nipigon is expected to produce snow squalls today. The most intense bands are expected later this morning along and southeast of Highway 11 between Lake Helen and Jellicoe. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible today. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T03:59:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T13:42:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1785645650.2019
Area: Beardmore - Jellicoe - Macdiarmid

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Cold westerly flow over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior is expected to produce snow squalls beginning today. The most intense bands are expected to develop later this afternoon and then continue through tonight into Wednesday. Locally heavy snowfall accumulations up to 15 cm per 12 hour period are likely with the snow squalls. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Island Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for the Cowichan Valley because of high concentrations of fine particulates that are expected to persist until weather conditions change. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Open burning restrictions are now in effect for the Cowichan Valley within 20 kilometres of Duncan City Hall for a period of 2 days. No new fires may be initiated and no additional material may be added to existing fires. For more information on burning restrictions, see the section entitled ‘Mandatory Emission Reduction Actions’ and for more information on current air quality, see: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### Exposure to air pollution is particularly a concern for children, the elderly, and those who have underlying medical conditions such as lung or heart disease. For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-11-06T01:08:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-11-05T09:41:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2544611187.2019
Area: Duncan
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall with local blowing snow is expected today and Wednesday. Snow at times heavy is expected today, tonight, and into Wednesday. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Wednesday. In addition, visibilities will be reduced in snow and blowing snow as northwesterly winds gusts could exceed 50 km/h. The snow is associated with a low pressure system near James Bay. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential storm affecting the Islands late in the week. A storm will likely develop Friday and affect the Magdalen Islands into the weekend. While it is too soon to provide specific details on precipitation, there is a possibility of accumulating snow, rainfall and strong winds. The storm will cause higher than normal water levels as well as large waves and rough and pounding surf, mainly along coastlines where winds blow onshore. It is too early to give specifics on impacts and areas to be affected. Additional information will be provided as it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T06:48:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T14:49:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1151230865.2019
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Early season snow squalls expected late Wednesday evening. Total snowfall: locally 10 cm or more over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km/h. Locations: west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: late Wednesday evening through early Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Snowfall accumulations along the coast are not expected to be significant as temperatures should remain near the freezing mark. However, for areas inland and over higher terrain, air temperatures will be cooler so snowfall accumulations could reach or exceed 10 cm and visibilities may be reduced in blowing snow. Conditions will improve Thursday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-06T06:29:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T14:30:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1543326543.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential storm over the Maritimes late in the week. A storm will likely develop Friday and affect Nova Scotia into the weekend. While it is too soon to provide specific details on precipitation types and amounts, there is a possibility of accumulating snow, heavy rainfall and strong winds. At this time, accumulating snow is looking less likely for Nova Scotia, especially for southern areas. Large waves may impact coastlines where strong winds blow onshore. This is most likely to occur over western Cape Breton where strong westerly winds blow onshore Friday night and Saturday. It is too early to give specifics on impacts and areas to be affected. Additional information will be provided as it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T06:45:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T14:46:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0480455312.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential storm over the Maritimes late in the week. A storm will likely develop Friday and affect Prince Edward Island into the weekend. While it is too soon to provide specific details on precipitation, there is a good possibility of accumulating snow for western parts of the Island, heavy rainfall and strong winds. In addition, there is a possibility of higher than normal water levels as well as large waves impacting coastlines where winds blow onshore. The highest risk is for parts of north to west facing coastlines. It is too early to give specifics on impacts and areas to be affected. Additional information will be provided as it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T06:43:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T14:44:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3511276014.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls will continue today and taper off this evening. Localized amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected in the snow squalls. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T03:08:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T11:09:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0625789713.2019
Area: Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
